Authors: Yeung O.M.; John J.A.J.A.P.C.M.E.; Muton N.B.R.
Author full names: Yeung, Ooi Ming (58547391200); John, Justtina Anantha Jothi A.P.C.M.E. (58547262300); Muton, Nursakirah Binti Ab Rahman (36608824000)
Title: Digitizing Receipts with OCR
Source title: International Journal of Computing and Digital Systems
Affiliations: Department of Computing, UOW Malaysia KDU Penang University College, Pulau Pinang, Malaysia
Authors with affiliations: Yeung O.M., Department of Computing, UOW Malaysia KDU Penang University College, Pulau Pinang, Malaysia; John J.A.J.A.P.C.M.E., Department of Computing, UOW Malaysia KDU Penang University College, Pulau Pinang, Malaysia; Muton N.B.R., Department of Computing, UOW Malaysia KDU Penang University College, Pulau Pinang, Malaysia
Abstract: Receipt digitization carries numerous advantages over traditional paper receipts in terms of preservation. Saving images of receipts is a method of digitizing receipts, but managing (sorting, searching, editing, deleting, adding annotations) them is rather tedious. This paper analyzes current receipt managing applications in the market, and their approach in digitizing receipts. Other researchers' methods were also analyzed, and a pipeline to achieve receipt digitization is deduced. With a pipeline of various methods in each step, the strengths and flaws of each method were addressed. Improvements to those methods and to the overall usability of a receipt management system were proposed. The proposed methods were then developed into a usable product application. © 2023 University of Bahrain. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Abbreviation Disambiguation; Field extraction; Image processing; Information Extraction; OCR; Optical Character Recognition

Authors: Ab Rahman Muton N.; Zakaria N.; Abdul-Talib A.-N.; Yusof S.A.M.
Author full names: Ab Rahman Muton, Nursakirah (36608824000); Zakaria, Norhayati (6603920595); Abdul-Talib, Asmat-Nizam (55636728000); Yusof, Shafiz Affendi Mohd (7003315049)
Title: Should I accommodate you? Cross-cultural code-switching behaviours of global virtual team members during swift trust formation
Source title: International Journal of Networking and Virtual Organisations
Affiliations: School of International Studies, College of Law, Government, and International Studies, Universiti Utara Malaysia, UUM Sintok, Kedah, 06010, Malaysia; Faculty of Business, UOWD Building, Dubai Knowledge Park, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Faculty of Engineering and Information Sciences, UOWD Building, Dubai Knowledge Park, Dubai, United Arab Emirates
Authors with affiliations: Ab Rahman Muton N., School of International Studies, College of Law, Government, and International Studies, Universiti Utara Malaysia, UUM Sintok, Kedah, 06010, Malaysia; Zakaria N., Faculty of Business, UOWD Building, Dubai Knowledge Park, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Abdul-Talib A.-N., School of International Studies, College of Law, Government, and International Studies, Universiti Utara Malaysia, UUM Sintok, Kedah, 06010, Malaysia; Yusof S.A.M., Faculty of Engineering and Information Sciences, UOWD Building, Dubai Knowledge Park, Dubai, United Arab Emirates
Abstract: This conceptual paper explores the process of cross-cultural code-switching (C3S) between high-context (HC) and low-context (LC) global virtual team members during the knowledge-sharing and social network exchanges. We will introduce a cross-cultural code-switching framework in a virtual setting and develop propositions to explain how GVT members attempt to switch their communicative behaviour based on two theoretical lenses: Giles communication accommodation theory (1973) and Hall high-context and low-context theory (1976). This paper offers several propositions to illuminate the process of code-switching behaviours among GVT members during the socialisation process and explores how these behaviours help develop swift trust. It considers whether developing swift trust is possible and, if so, how. We will provide future research directions in our concluding remarks.  © 2022 Inderscience Enterprises Ltd.
Author Keywords: CAT; communication accommodation theory; communication styles; communicative behaviour; Cross-cultural code-switching behaviour; global virtual teams; GVTs; high-context and low-context cultures; knowledge sharing; Malaysia

Authors: Muton N.Ab.R.; Zakaria N.; Damanhoori F.
Author full names: Muton, Nursakirah Ab.Rahman (36608824000); Zakaria, Nasriah (25825811600); Damanhoori, Faten (36467854100)
Title: A conceptual framework of an e-mentoring system for orphan children using arcs motivational model
Source title: Proceedings 2010 International Symposium on Information Technology - System Development and Application and Knowledge Society, ITSim'10
Affiliations: School of Computer Sciences, Universiti Sains Malaysia, 11800, Minden, Penang, Malaysia
Authors with affiliations: Muton N.Ab.R., School of Computer Sciences, Universiti Sains Malaysia, 11800, Minden, Penang, Malaysia; Zakaria N., School of Computer Sciences, Universiti Sains Malaysia, 11800, Minden, Penang, Malaysia; Damanhoori F., School of Computer Sciences, Universiti Sains Malaysia, 11800, Minden, Penang, Malaysia
Abstract: This paper discusses a conceptual framework for the design of an e-mentoring system specifically for orphan children as protégés of their adult mentors. We propose using the ARCS motivational model as the theoretical model because motivation is one of the most important aspects of the mentoring process. We review the historical perspective of ARCS, discuss the previous works that used ARCS, and propose the design of our e-mentoring system. The ARCS model was developed by John M. Keller in 1987 as an effective approach for stimulating motivation among students. We discuss how to customize videoconferencing, an important element in e-mentoring based on the ARCS design strategies. © 2010 IEEE.
Author Keywords: ARCS motivational model; Design process; E-mentoring
Index Keywords: Information technology; Motivation; Video conferencing; ARCS model; ARCS motivational model; Conceptual frameworks; Design process; Design strategies; E-Mentoring; Historical perspective; Theoretical models; Design

Authors: Zakaria N.; Yusof S.A.M.; Muton N.A.R.
Author full names: Zakaria, Norhayati (6603920595); Yusof, Shafiz Affendi Mohd (7003315049); Muton, Nursakirah Ab Rahman (36608824000)
Title: Virtually, you are there! exploring the teamwork challenges to swift trust formation when working in global virtual team
Affiliations: School of International Studies, College of Law, Government and International Studies, Universiti Utara Malaysia, Sintok, 06010, Kedah, Malaysia; School of Computing, College of Arts and Science, Universiti Utara Malaysia, Sintok, 06010, Kedah, Malaysia
Authors with affiliations: Zakaria N., School of International Studies, College of Law, Government and International Studies, Universiti Utara Malaysia, Sintok, 06010, Kedah, Malaysia; Yusof S.A.M., School of Computing, College of Arts and Science, Universiti Utara Malaysia, Sintok, 06010, Kedah, Malaysia; Muton N.A.R., School of International Studies, College of Law, Government and International Studies, Universiti Utara Malaysia, Sintok, 06010, Kedah, Malaysia
Abstract: Due to the nature of the GVT work structure in which people are unconstrained by geographic boundaries, teams must also cope with conflicting cultural values and time zone differences. This factor creates many challenges, in particular with a group of people who are strangers to one another and has no historical background of working together. The main purpose of this exploratory study is to highlight the challenges of swift trust formation within GVTs and to present the teamwork-related issues involved in globally distributed collaboration. We conducted two focus group interviews to develop a preliminary understanding of the phenomenon based on the Tuckman and Jensen (1997) teamwork model. This data yielded important insights into the initial process of teamwork and swift trust formation. Based on our findings, team members experienced key challenges such as delayed communication due to time differences, misunderstanding of tasks assigned, technical problems with the use of varied collaborative tools, work attitude, lack of responsibility and motivation among teams and difficulty to establish relationships. © 2015 American Scientific Publishers. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Cultural values; Global virtual teams; Swift trust; Teamwork

Authors: Damanhoori F.; Ab.Rahman Muton N.; Zakaria N.; Mustaffa N.
Author full names: Damanhoori, Faten (36467854100); Ab.Rahman Muton, Nursakirah (36608824000); Zakaria, Nasriah (25825811600); Mustaffa, Norlia (36608754600)
Title: E-mentoring system development using ARCS motivational strategies
Affiliations: School of Computer Sciences, Universiti Sains Malaysia, Penang, Malaysia
Authors with affiliations: Damanhoori F., School of Computer Sciences, Universiti Sains Malaysia, Penang, Malaysia; Ab.Rahman Muton N., School of Computer Sciences, Universiti Sains Malaysia, Penang, Malaysia; Zakaria N., School of Computer Sciences, Universiti Sains Malaysia, Penang, Malaysia; Mustaffa N., School of Computer Sciences, Universiti Sains Malaysia, Penang, Malaysia
Abstract: An e-mentoring system is an online tool that enables interactive mentoring between a mentor and a mentee, regardless of place and time differences. This paper discusses the system design of an e-mentoring system for Malaysian orphans, called MyMentorMentee.com. The design of MyMentorMentee.com is an adaptation of Keller's ARCS Motivational model and uses its motivational elements to provide an effective mentoring experience for each session. A (attention), R (relevance), C (confidence) and S (satisfaction) are the four components of the ARCS motivational model. Keller's model provides techniques for solving the motivational problems faced by a learner during the learning process. The purpose of MyMentorMentee.com is to study how an e-mentoring system can overcome the motivational challenges faced by orphans which were identified during the preliminary study. Among these are personal issues and learning issues. The system was developed to help mentor and mentee to carry out the mentoring session using alternative (web-based) way at anytime and anywhere. The system that we have designed has 4 modules: personal profile, text messaging, mentoring schedule, and personal video chat. All modules were evaluated using quantitative and qualitative techniques.
Author Keywords: ARCS Motivational Model; E-mentoring system; System design
Index Keywords: E-Mentoring; Learning process; Malaysians; On-line tools; Personal profile; System development; Time-differences; Systems analysis

Authors: Zakaria N.; Ab Rahman Muton N.
Author full names: Zakaria, Norhayati (6603920595); Ab Rahman Muton, Nursakirah (36608824000)
Title: Cultural code-switching in high context global virtual team members: A qualitative study
Source title: International Journal of Cross Cultural Management
Affiliations: University of Sharjah, Sharjah, United Arab Emirates; UOW Malaysia KDU Penang University College, Malaysia
Authors with affiliations: Zakaria N., University of Sharjah, Sharjah, United Arab Emirates; Ab Rahman Muton N., UOW Malaysia KDU Penang University College, Malaysia
Abstract: Global virtual teams (GVTs) are a prevalent work structure that enable people to accomplish tasks across time, space, and cultural boundaries and perform cross-culturally. However, few studies have highlighted what exact behaviors enable GVTs to share knowledge effectively. Based on a qualitative study using semi-structured interviews with 22 respondents from various multinational corporations (MNCs) in Malaysia, we answer the following overarching research question: Why do high context members switch their communicative behaviors amongst foreign team members within global virtual teams? Our study provides detailed narratives of high-context team members becoming the behavioral “switchers” to collaborate and share knowledge with their foreign team members effectively. Our study defines and clarifies the concept of cross-cultural code-switching as a key behavior reflecting effective cross-cultural performance when accommodating foreign team members’ communicative behaviours by adopting (1) directness in speech, (2) openness during knowledge sharing, and (3) task-oriented aims. This study addresses several gaps in the field of cross-cultural management by extending Hall’s (1976) theoretical lens on high-context and low-context cultures, Molinsky’s (2007) cross-cultural code-switching concept in the context of the virtual work structure, and the criterion space surrounding cross cultural performance. © The Author(s) 2022.
Author Keywords: code-switching; global virtual teams; high-context; knowledge sharing; Malaysia; qualitative

Authors: Yusof S.A.M.; Zakaria N.; Muton N.A.R.
Author full names: Yusof, Shafiz Affendi Mohd (56111373400); Zakaria, Norhayati (6603920595); Muton, Nursakirah Ab Rahman (36608824000)
Title: Timely trust: The use of IoT and cultural effects on swift trust formation within global virtual teams
Source title: ICIT 2017 - 8th International Conference on Information Technology, Proceedings
Affiliations: Faculty of Engineering and Information Sciences, University of Wollongong in Dubai, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Faculty of Business and Management, University of Wollongong in Dubai, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; School of International Studies, College of Law, Government and International Studies, Universiti Utara Malaysia, Sintok, Kedah, 06010, Malaysia
Authors with affiliations: Yusof S.A.M., Faculty of Engineering and Information Sciences, University of Wollongong in Dubai, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Zakaria N., Faculty of Business and Management, University of Wollongong in Dubai, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Muton N.A.R., School of International Studies, College of Law, Government and International Studies, Universiti Utara Malaysia, Sintok, Kedah, 06010, Malaysia
Abstract: This paper explores the possible use of the Internet of Things (IoT) in the context of global virtual teams (GVTs) and its cultural effect on swift trust formation within GVTs. For multinational corporations (MNCs), it is deemed timely for organizations to capitalize on the IoT environment since it is grounded by the "Global Village" phenomenon. The main research question is: How do GVTs capitalize on IoT to achieve high performing teams, and what is the cultural effect of IoT on swift trust formation in a GVT? In this paper, we develop propositions to explain the different types of tools and services potentially used by GVTs and how these tools can impact the way quick trust is formulated among GVT members when they collaborate at a distance. This conceptual paper will also provide future research directions. © 2017 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Global Virtual Team; Internet of Things (IoT); Swift Trust
Index Keywords: Computer supported cooperative work; Industrial management; Cultural effects; Future research directions; Global virtual teams; Internet of thing (IOT); Internet of Things (IOT); Multi-national corporations; Research questions; Swift trust; Internet of things

Authors: Midi N.A.; Idrus R.; Muton N.A.R.
Author full names: Midi, Nur Akma (57210867774); Idrus, Rosnah (6507359601); Muton, Nursakirah Ab Rahman (36608824000)
Title: Web accessibility of Malaysian research universities websites for the visually impaired
Source title: 2014 the 4th International Workshop on Computer Science and Engineering-Winter, WCSE 2014
Affiliations: School of Computer Sciences, Universiti Sains Malaysia, Penang, 11800, Malaysia
Authors with affiliations: Midi N.A., School of Computer Sciences, Universiti Sains Malaysia, Penang, 11800, Malaysia; Idrus R., School of Computer Sciences, Universiti Sains Malaysia, Penang, 11800, Malaysia; Muton N.A.R., School of Computer Sciences, Universiti Sains Malaysia, Penang, 11800, Malaysia
Abstract: The Internet has become a part of us and an increasingly important source of information. Web accessibility refers to making websites usable, understandable and contributable by people with and without disabilities. Universities. web sites often sought after resources in education and users visit those websites for many reasons; hence it should be accessible for all users anytime and anywhere. However, some information in the universities. websites is inaccessible especially by visually impaired users. This study aims to investigate the web accessibility problems or any obstacles visually impaired users encounter when they visit the Malaysia universities. websites. Websites from five research universities in Malaysia are used and a comparative analysis is performed with WCAG 2.0. Respondents are visually impaired university students and students from a school for the blinds. They are asked to perform a series of tasks on samples of those universities. websites to assess the website.s accessibility features. Findings of the study provide recommendations for web developers to improve the university website design in order to facilitate better access by the visually impaired users.
Author Keywords: University website; Visually impaired users; WCAG 2.0; Web accessibility
Index Keywords: Education; Social networking (online); Societies and institutions; Transportation; World Wide Web; Comparative analysis; Research universities; University students; Visually impaired; Visually-impaired users; WCAG 2.0; Web accessibility; Web site design; Websites

Author full names: Zakaria, Norhayati (6603920595); Muton, Nursakirah Ab Rahman (36608824000)
Title: It's not that simple! intel-cultural communication adaptive behaviors of high-context global virtual team members
Affiliations: School of International Studies, Government and International Studies, College of Law, Universiti Utara Malaysia, Sintok, Kedah Darul Aman, 06010, Malaysia
Authors with affiliations: Zakaria N., School of International Studies, Government and International Studies, College of Law, Universiti Utara Malaysia, Sintok, Kedah Darul Aman, 06010, Malaysia; Muton N.A.R., School of International Studies, Government and International Studies, College of Law, Universiti Utara Malaysia, Sintok, Kedah Darul Aman, 06010, Malaysia
Abstract: This paper explores the process of cultural adaptation among high-context global virtual team (GVT) members when communicating with low context members, specifically how do team members adapt and attune their communication styles to one another? In this paper, we develop propositions to explain how and why high-context GVT members adapt their communication styles, and discuss the approach employed by high-context GVT members to adjust their communicative behavior when communicating interculturally. © 2016 International Information Institute.
Author Keywords: Communication accommodation theory (CAT); Cultural adaptation behavior (CAB); Cultural adaptation process; Hall high-context and low- context culture (HC/LC); Intercultural communication
